comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Crops from this picture (see comments there): Eliseo Arredondo Luis Peredo

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: The whole group belongs presumably to the Carranza agency in Washington. Another photo shows five of these persons under the title "CARRANZA GOVERNMENT IS WELL REPRESENTED IN WASHINGTON", see the Bisbee daily review, April 18, 1915, Page 1 Jose Maria Arredondo was a second cousin to Eliseo Arredondo and when the latter was Mexican ambassador to the United States at Washington, served under him for two years as private secretary (Bisbee daily review, August 13, 1918, Page 8: SKILLED DIPLOMAT SENT AS CONSUL TO DOUGLAS)

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Note scribal error, should be Duplan, not Duplin. Óscar E. Duplan Maldonado (* 17. April 1890 in Pichucalco; † 23. April 1942 in Ciudad de México) was a Mexican Ambassador (de.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C3%93scar_E._Dupl%C3%A1n, in German (!) See also www.old-picture.com/american-legacy/012/Duplan-Oscar-E.htm

comment.author: 34911459@N08
comment._content: B-59: thanks for the additional information about the group of men as well as for the correct spelling.  We will update the database record.

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Luis d'Antin, an American citizen, was chancellor of the American embassy in Mexico and later attached to the Mexican embassy in the US. He suffered a sudden death in San Luis Potosi while enroute to Mexico City with Eliseo Arredondo in 1917, see the Bisbee daily review, January 10, 1917, Page 4 "AMERICAN CITIZEN ATTACHE OF MEXICO EMBASSY IS DEAD".

comment.author: 66311327@N05
comment._content: Francisco Paredo: His correct name was presumably Francisco Peredo, he was the Mexican consul in Phoenix until 1920, see El Paso herald, May 14, 1920, HOME EDITION, Image 1 last column: MEXICAN CONSULATE AT PHOENIX, ARIZONA, CLOSED Bisbee daily review., July 29, 1919, Page 4, second column: MEXICAN CONSUL TO AID IN FIGHT ON MARIHUANA and others only (as I can see) El Paso herald., January 28, 1918, HOME EDITION, Page 3 El Paso herald., January 28, 1918, HOME EDITION, Page 3 third column ("Would Be Carnal House") called him Francisco Paredo
